Room seemed cold - nothing either French bistro or theatrical about it.  Seems like a missed opportunity. 

 Text2: Like any good smokehouse, this place gets your appetite going before you walk in the door.  As we walked a block or so (to avoid the road work on 118 avenue), we could smell the great smoke and we were even more excited to try their range of meats.  Spoiler: it is the best low and slow in town.

We started with quick peruse of the menu and settled on ribs but were told they needed some more time in the smoker, so went with plan B - pulled pork sandwich and an order of brisket and gravy.  

Pulled pork was moist and tender served in a bunwich with a little coleslaw for crunch.  Had a choice of three barbeque sauces and went with the house sauce which was good. A great deal at $9.

The brisket and gravy was amazing.  Meat was so tender, and the gravy outstanding with a good amount of garlic. Unexpectedly, the baked beans were every bit as good, and again full of flavour, not a second thought as they often are.  

The chef let me try the chicken thigh as it came out of the smoker and it was so delicious that next time, I may have to forego the ribs again for more chicken.

Portions are huge and the flavours great.  This is place is going to be hit, so get in now while you can.

Other than that, a stellar experience!

The heat and mass of people in the shop did not make the experience any better, some ladies started to get worked up with me when they misunderstood me talking to my friends. Standing and watching the ice cream being made and rolled is pretty cool unless you're literally watching 10s of ice creams being made that aren't yours. It's an interesting concept, but they really need to expedite it some how, they had a whole rolling station that was not being utilized even with enough workers to man it. Also only having one girl topping the ice creams created a real and tangible bottle neck in service. I'm glad I came with friends because we didn't get the same ice creams and I could taste a bunch of different kinds. The ice cream is harder and icier than I'd like and had week flavor. The toppings don't really do much to add flavor but they look great for the obligatory Instagram photo. I don't think I'd want to waste another 2 hours to get a mediocre ice cream.

 Text1: What a wonderful experience!!! I cannot wait to go back and bring some friends!

My boyfriend took me here as a surprise date, but I had seen great reviews about it. The venue itself is very small, and doesn't take reservations so we had to wait 20 minutes until we got seated. The doorman was pleasant enough though, giving us the option of sitting outside under the heated lamps (we turned this down, since we were both very cold).

We ordered the prosciutto plate as an appetizer, which had delicious bread and pickles/condiments on the side. The waitress was extremely accomodating and gave us gluten-free crackers instead of the bread, to accomodate my boyfriend. We are both wine and cheese noobs, so our waitress was extremely patient in explaining the different types of wine and asking us what we would prefer;  her recommendations were spot-on. 

We choose two cheeses, both of which came with a special fig sauce that complemented their tastes PERFECTLY. We had a great time talking about what exactly made certain foods go well together, as it seems like Tria has gotten it down to a science!!

Great ambience, perfect for a date or a girls' night out if you're feeling like being classy. Prices were affordable for the quality of food and experience!

The karaoke machines all have pretty up to date songs in a variety of languages. 

 Text2: I really loved Claim Jumper my first couple times there! But recently, its seemed to be going downhill.  (boo!!!)
The past couple times I've gone I've felt a bit ripped off - like I paid way too much for mediocre food. This last time sealed the deal and I'm sad to say we probably won't return (there's way too many other fantastic places to eat at!)
We went for happy hour and were super disappointed! We ordered cocktails (margarita for me, mojito for my friend) and they were just "meh." We started with a shrimp and avocado salsa. Although the flavors were good, the preparation of the salsa was a joke! It came out with the bottom half being chopped up shimp and salsa. On top was a quarter of an avocado, basically sitting in one chunk. I couldn't believe they didn't even bother to mix it together - pure laziness on part of the chef!
I got a mini bbq chicken pizza afterward, which was alright. Nothing special, but not bad either. My friend got a burger that was TERRIBLE! I guess after the burger is cooked they put cheese on top and throw it under the broiler for a bit to melt the cheese. Well, they must have forgotten about it, because the cheese was completely burned! It was disgusting!! Inedible!! When she sent it back, the manager came out with the "fixed" burger (same burger patty - new cheese on top), but didn't offer to comp a drink, or appetizer, or anything. Having worked in the restaurant industry for years, I find this to be a mistake on her part. After the "fix" the burger was still pretty gross. After being double-cooked the meat was tough and dried out and the toppings (lettuce, onion rings, etc.) were now soggy and gross.

Sad to see that CJ has jumped the ship, so to speak, but it appears it has. Get it together, CJ, or we won't be back!

The correct answer is no. The writing styles of Text1 and Text2 suggest they were written by different authors.

instruction:
Please decide if the following Text1 and Text2 are written by the same authors. 'yes' means from the same author, 'no' means not from the same author. Then, provide an analysis based on writing styles.  

 Text1: (to the tune of Niall Horan's "Slow Hands")

She said "Dinner by the parkway."
So I took the bus all the way.
Cause I'm craving guac
and I just can't stop.
I've been thinking 'bout it all day
Tacos sitting in my bell-ay.
Batter fry those fish
Put them on my dish, baby

My hands
Got sauce dripping down, but I'm not stopping.
No chance
That I won't pick back up that bite I'm dropping
I know
Yeah, I already know I want another
I got big plans for tacos
in my hands, baby.

Good tacos (fish is totally worth the extra 50 cents), great guac (steep price made more clear by the HUGE portion size), and their fountain soda is fancy AF. Garces does a bang-up job, typically.

Friend got a salad topped with "shrimp" (extra $5) and got 5 individual shrimp. A dollar per shrimp feels a little silly, they were very petite. We ordered some sides, too, which weirdly came about 7 minutes before our taco entrees with our guac - would prefer them to come simultaneously, as they were hot and cooled down a bit by taco time. 

 Text2: 1 Tippling Place: Come for the cocktails, stick around for the giant zebra head and attentive service. Less pomp than some of the other fancy schmancy cocktail spots, I'll continue tippling at Tippling Place for happy hours, dates, and any booze-gathering you can think to put together. 

Brighter than Ranstead Room, easier to dress for than Hop SIng, and cheaper than Franklin Mortgage, 1 Tippling is the place I go to when I want a cocktail without making a whole "thing" about it. Grab some casual appetizers (bacon wrapped dates, artichoke dip), enjoy a few of the happy hour offerings (big fan of the fish bowl punch, a steal at $5), and chat with your buddies around the accessible tables that don't mandate a strict dress code to stand/sit around... You'll leave with a saucy buzz, and a smile on your face from the attentive and knowledgeable staff. 

Bathrooms are trendy and always clean, no formal "coat check" but a bunch of hangers just waiting to hold onto your outerwear for any length of time, and all the chotskies one could hang on a wall without drifting into TGIFridays territory, 1TP is a solid spot that I've gradually begun to make a regular in my circulation of must-drink bars...
output:
The correct answer is yes. The writing styles of Text1 and Text2 show distinctive characteristics that indicate they were written by different authors.

Sentence Structure and Syntax: Text1 uses short, fragmented sentences and repetition to create a song-like rhythm. Text2 uses longer, more complex sentences with a more straightforward syntax.

Punctuation Style: Text1 uses ellipses for pauses and emphasis, while Text2 uses standard punctuation without any particular stylistic features.

Compound and Separate Spelling: Both texts adhere to standard spelling conventions.

Acronyms and Abbreviations: Text1 uses "AF" as an abbreviation for "as f***." Text2 does not use any acronyms or abbreviations.

Characters Style: Text1 introduces characters and describes their actions in relation to the author's experience. Text2 does not mention any specific characters.

Diatopic Variations and Foreign Languages: Neither text includes foreign languages or significant diatopic variations.

Grab some casual appetizers (bacon wrapped dates, artichoke dip), enjoy a few of the happy hour offerings (big fan of the fish bowl punch, a steal at $5), and chat with your buddies around the accessible tables that don't mandate a strict dress code to stand/sit around... You'll leave with a saucy buzz, and a smile on your face from the attentive and knowledgeable staff. 

Bathrooms are trendy and always clean, no formal "coat check" but a bunch of hangers just waiting to hold onto your outerwear for any length of time, and all the chotskies one could hang on a wall without drifting into TGIFridays territory, 1TP is a solid spot that I've gradually begun to make a regular in my circulation of must-drink bars... 

 Text2: Yet another great experience here with the beer bread, sirloin special (that came with a savory mushroom bread pudding and creamed spinach), and tuna special (that came with green beans in hoisin sauce and soba noodle patties).  I tried a strawberry cider that was dryer than I expected.  All in all, another wonderful experience and worth the 25 min wait at 6pm on a Sat. evening.

Please decide if the following Text1 and Text2 are written by the same authors. 'yes' means from the same author, 'no' means not from the same author. Then, provide an analysis based on writing styles.  

 Text1: Love the fish bowl for $10! Lines are always confusing here when it's crowded with folks merging in line from both sides. It's worth the wait but not worth fighting over who cut in line. The folks serving do their best to accomodate customers. 

 Text2: I'd been looking for a convenient, reasonably priced, quick service place to stop for breakfast (or is it dinner?) after working overnights. Mel's Kitchen fits the bill.

Mel's is located in a small stand-alone building on Umbria St. Slightly dilapidated, it easily goes unnoticed unless you happen to know of it's existence (thanks to Yelp, of course). 

The first time I went was around 8 am. I seated myself at one of 3 open tables (4 in total) and Mel herself came over and poured me a cup of coffee in a brightly colored mug. That was the first moment I started to fall in love with this place: Mel doesn't use those miniature white coffee mugs you see in most diners - these mugs are huge and look like she took them right out of her own personal kitchen. 

The second thing that struck me was that there's Sriracha on every table. Mel's clearly knows the best breakfast condiment and doesn't make you request it.

Despite my love of Sriracha I was craving something sweet, so I ordered the French toast and bacon (extra crispy). The kitchen is in the same room as the dining area so I was able to watch Mel happily work away on my food while she cooked a few breakfast sandwiches for the customers sitting at the bar right in front of the griddle. Clearly those patrons were regulars as they chatted about their kids' little league and the scorching hot weather.

Soon my breakfast was delivered to me and oh my, was it delicious! The bacon was perfectly crispy and the French toast was delectable. The portion was quite large - 3 slices of toast and about 5 strips of bacon.

I think my bill was about $8. Of course I didn't notice the large sign stating they take credit card for bills over $10 - so I threw in a Mel's Kitchen t-shirt (which is a really cute play off of the Hell's Kitchen logo).

With all the thoughtful touches and Mel's down to earth, amiable personality I truly felt at home here. I've since been back for take out breakfast sandwiches and I continue to be impressed by the service and food quality. This is now my favorite no-frills breakfast spot.
output:

instruction:
Please decide if the following Text1 and Text2 are written by the same authors. 'yes' means from the same author, 'no' means not from the same author. Then, provide an analysis based on writing styles.  

 Text1: We were at the mall and decided to get a milkshake and some nibbles.  We both ordered chocolate shakes and one order of the riblet appetizer.  As a suggestion, order the larger version of the milkshake because the normal size is only about 10 oz.  Personally, I do not care for sprinkles on a milkshake. The riblets were tasty but for the price($9) we only got 6, one inch long portions of them on a bed of potato chips.  In short, it was a very meager appetizer for the price.

Bottom line:  We should have gone to the food court. 

 Text2: Because of other reviews, we thought it was high time that we stop by here for lunch.  With the salt water lobster tank smells and all of the aerators going, the atmosphere is very unique.  The staff is very friendly and welcoming.  

They have a limited menu chocked full of lobster dishes.  We had hoped for some raw oysters but the only ones available were the $15.99/dozen ones that were a bit too rich for my blood...OK, I can be rather cheap.  Our fall-back appetizer was the smoked fish spread.  It was a nice smokey heap of spread dusted with cayenne .  Most wonderfully, the Club Crackers were not in individual wrappers!  Our waitress also brought some toasted bread slices to slather on more fish spread.  

As soon as we were through with the spread, our lobster rolls arrived.  At first, they looked a bit smallish but awesome, nonetheless.  The plate came with crisp potato chips and your choice of either slaw or potato salad and we got the potato salad.  The roll was piled with goodly sized portions of lobster and two complete pieces of claw meat.  It also had a small swipe of mayonnaise on the roll as well as a lettuce leaf on a nicely toasted square bun.  The taste of the lobster was delicate, texture firm and visually ideal.  I would have asked for a lemon wedge to squeeze on it but all in all,  it was tasty. 

Please check the on-line menu before you go because you could have a bit of 'sticker shock' from the prices. Do not think that you are going to get a fancy lobster dinner here.  It is a great casual, get-your-shirt-dirty kind of dining experience.  Please give it a try!
output:
The correct answer is yes. Based on the analysis of the characteristics of writing style, here are reasons why Text1 and Text2 were written by the same author:

Writing Style: Both texts have a conversational and personal writing style, with the author sharing their experiences and opinions about specific food establishments.

Expressions and Idioms: Both texts use expressions and idioms to enhance the narrative and convey the author's thoughts and feelings, such as "in short" in Text1 and "fall-back appetizer" in Text2.

Tone and Mood: The tone in both texts is informal and relaxed, with the author expressing their personal preferences and offering suggestions in a friendly manner.

Sentence Structure and Syntax: Both texts use a mix of shorter and longer sentences, with a straightforward syntax that focuses on conveying information and opinions clearly.

Punctuation Style: Both texts use standard punctuation, but Text1 includes more exclamation points for emphasis.

Special Characters and Capitalization Style: Neither text uses special characters or unique capitalization styles.

Compound and Separate Spelling: Both texts adhere to standard spelling conventions.

Acronyms and Abbreviations: Neither text uses acronyms or abbreviations.

Characters Style: Both texts describe characters (staff, the author themselves) and their actions or qualities in relation to the author's experience.

Diatopic Variations and Foreign Languages: Neither text includes foreign languages or significant diatopic variations.

Other Relevant Aspects: Both texts provide specific details and descriptions about the food and dining experiences, such as the size and price of milkshakes in Text1 and the taste and presentation of lobster rolls in Text2.

In conclusion, the similar writing style, tone, sentence structure, and content focus indicate that Text1 and Text2 were written by the same author.

instruction:
Please decide if the following Text1 and Text2 are written by the same authors. 'yes' means from the same author, 'no' means not from the same author. Then, provide an analysis based on writing styles.  

 Text1: We were at the mall and decided to get a milkshake and some nibbles.  We both ordered chocolate shakes and one order of the riblet appetizer.  As a suggestion, order the larger version of the milkshake because the normal size is only about 10 oz.  Personally, I do not care for sprinkles on a milkshake. The riblets were tasty but for the price($9) we only got 6, one inch long portions of them on a bed of potato chips.  In short, it was a very meager appetizer for the price.

Bottom line:  We should have gone to the food court. 

 Text2: I've always dreaded having to write a review about this place but unfortunately I was forced to go to the University of Penn Vet hospital with my 11 month poodle Sammy after my mom had a accident while grooming him. This resulted in a large gash on the side of his neck. It was yesterday (a Sunday afternoon) and therefore, all of the "vet hospitals" in my area were closed. I don't think they should be considered hospitals if they don't take emergency visits. I've heard of Univ. of Penn in the past and heard it is very expensive but I didn't have a choice at this point. I was disappointed that I was never told what a great hospital this was for emergency cases.

We were seen by a nurse within 2 seconds of our arrival. We did not call ahead. He was taken back right away and a nurse took information about what happened. We waited about five minutes then were asked if its ok to give him pain medication through a catheter. Of course we said it was ok. About 10 minutes after that they asked us to come to the back again for another report of what happened. We explained again and they were very interested in the scissors that were used in case there was bacteria or rust they should be worried about. We explained the scissors and were told exactly what they were going to do to our little Sammy. We were told it would take 2 hours to clean him up so we were able to go home and come back. 

3 stitches, $420 bucks (no pet insurance) and 2 1/2 hours later, Sammy was back at home completely shaved, nails cut and surprisingly full of energy. The stitches will have to be removed in 10-14 days but according to the doc, this will be free of charge. We also have the option of removing them at our regular Vet's office. 

The hospital was very impressive. You'd think it was a hospital for people. The staff was quick but thorough and very nice. UPenn is definitely expensive but you could tell where the money is going. Even if you wish you'd never have to visit this place, you should at least know where it is in case of an emergency. Or look for the closest 24 hr hospital in your area.

Sentence Structure and Syntax: Text1 uses shorter sentences and a more straightforward syntax, while Text2 uses longer, more complex sentences and a sophisticated syntax.

 Text2: Where do I begin? I moved to Palm Harbor 17 months ago. I dreamed I would be able to find a non-corporate, personable cafe and coffee shop to come to in the morning, meet friends, have a great cuppa, and contemplate the scent of the beautiful gulf breeze. I found that and a lot more at Old Town!

The coffee is from Baby's Coffee with roasting locations in Key West, Florida and Breaux Bridge, Louisiana, The bread is from Giovanni's Bakery in Largo, Fl. Desserts and pies come from J.J. Gandy's (famous for their Key Lime pies) right here in Palm Harbor.

The breakfast items include, bagels croissants, paninis,  all available as sandwiches. I've almost tried them all as I will never turn away an offered bite from friends!  Belgian Waffles, a breakfast Cuban, Panini, or Burrito? No worries. Breakfast is available all day!

But the choice of sandwiches, salads, soups, and wraps go on and on for great cafe lunches. I can't do it justice. I can say that as I'm doing this review, I'm inspired by the amazing Chicken Salad sandwich (w chopped grapes), with fresh lettuce and tomatoes on whole wheat! 

There was recently a turnover in ownership. This has not affected the great service and friendliness as a familiar staff member/customer took the reins. In fact, they are constantly asking their customers, local and new, for ideas. 

Yes, many mornings on the front deck, my friends and I are enjoying the menu, sharing random thoughts, and loving the coastal life at Old Town Cafe. Sweet!
